titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Went to Church this morning, at the Foundling Hospital and heard Mr: Hewlett. Walk afterwards in the Park and in Kensington Gardens. The two Miss Bancroft’s and Messrs: Boylston, Hall, Murdoch, Jeffrey and Shaw dined with us.

2. Continue writing the observations mentioned above; for which I find myself however very much shortened for want of time. Mrs: Adams very ill the whole day, though somewhat recovering in the Evening.— I find my cares accumulating as I advance in life: and henceforth some portion of my time must be allotted to an attention to my own affairs. Called at Leader’s the Coach maker’s.— Evening reading Peltier’s last number.

3. Called this forenoon upon Mr: d’Asp the Swedish Minister but he was not at home. From thence upon Sir Francis Baring in Devonshire Square, and on his Bankers. Thence walked to the Coach maker’s and home.— Mrs: Court passed the Evening here.— Received Letters and Newspapers from America.

4. Mrs: A. very ill great part of the night.— Mr: Wadsworth called in the forenoon; an hour or two of conversation with him. Finished at length my observations.— Making slowly some preparations for our departure. Our Captain called on me. Thinks of going next Sunday.

5. Mr: d’Asp called on me this morning. Informed him of my full powers to renew our Treaty with Sweden. Visit in the forenoon from Mr: Wadsworth & Mr: Ross. Dined with Mrs: Court: Mrs: Hewlett, and his pupil Mr: Horner there. We all went in the Evening to Drury Lane Theatre, and saw Hamlet.— with the Devil to pay.— Mrs: Jordan’s Ophelia good.

6. Visit in the forenoon from Sir Francis Baring. Mr: Boylston called on us between 12. and 1. We went to the British Museum, where we saw no object of very remarkable curiosity. An original of the great charter appeared the principal— A miniature of Cromwell by Cooper and some portraits deserved notice. I have seen another original of Magna Charta at Oxford.— I paid some visits in the City, and did some little business. In the Evening we went to Covent Garden theatre and saw Much ado about nothing—with diamond cut diamond. Mrs: Abington after many years retirement from the Stage returned and appeared in the character of Beatrice.— She was old—very old—and grows fat. But all things considered, performed the part very well. Lewis in Benedick was very good.— The farce was intolerable.

7. I passed the principal part of the morning at visiting in the City.— At Sir F. Baring’s. Mr: Medford. Mr: Dorr’s. found the last at home. Mr: Medford had called upon me on Thursday with a letter from Mr: Coffin junr: in 1795. then a member of Congress.— Dined with Mr: Boylston.— Mr: Abbot Mr: Smith, and one or two other Gentlemen there.— Mr: Vaughan called in the Evening.— Mr: Abbot though an Englishman is a native of Constantinople, and has views of commercial dealings between America and Turkey.— He will call upon me.— When I came home, found a letter from Mr: Gerry at Rotterdam, and one from Mr: Delius at Bremen. The latter a very unpleasant and improper one.— Mrs: A. dined with Mrs: Court.

8. Went to Church at the foundling hospital, and heard an excellent and very applicable sermon from Mr: Hewlett. Walked afterwards in the Park, and in Kensington Gardens.— Wrote a little upon my return home. Began a letter to my mother.— Mr: Hewlett and Mr: Hall dined with us. the latter passed the evening with us too— Pleasantly.— Mr: Barnes, an American, called on me to ask for letters of introduction. He has an old recommendatory from Mr: Jefferson.

9. Our Captain who was to have sailed yesterday postpones his departure as usual from day to day. Had a number of visitors in the course of the forenoon. Dined with Mr: Medford at N. 50 Finsbury Square, with a number of Americans— Lyle a stock-jobbing Jacobin—the others all apparently decent.— Rogers, Murdoch, Ross, a Mr: Stuart, and a Doctor Tate, with an English Gentleman.— Conversed with Mr: Murdoch after dinner.— Find the affairs of Mr: J. more & more adverse— This trial is a strong one—more so indeed than I expected—and I expected it would be strong.— I have done my duty—rigorous, inflexible duty, and no Event whatsoever shall convince me that by pursuing a more interested, and less faithful course, I should have been rewarded with better success.— Mrs: A. dined with her friend Mrs: Cadignan at Hackney.

10. Visits again from numerous quarters.— Mr: W. & Miss Vaughan— Mr Barnes— Mr: Poggi, Dr: Bancroft &c. I am endeavouring to write and to read as much as I can.— Mrs: Hewlett dined and passed the evening with us.— Passed it partly myself in my chamber, reading Peltier’s last number, and Mr: Abbot’s project for establishing an intercourse between the United States and Turkey— The subject is important to our commerce.

11. Called at Mr: Abbot’s this forenoon to return him his papers.— He asked me for letters of introduction which I told him I would give him.— Such as I can give with propriety.— In the state of suspense between the time fixed for departing and the departure.— My brother dined abroad.— Finished the 3d: and last volume of Bertrand’s private memoirs.— Purchased the Memoirs of Bouillé. Mrs: A. somewhat unwell—

12. Making preparations for departure. Visits in the forenoon— Mrs: Cadignan & her uncle. Mrs: Court and her daughter and Mr: Murdoch with us at tea and the remainder of the Evening. We had Letters this morning from Mrs: Johnson, and Mrs: Court had one from Nancy written at Stromness in one of the Orkney Islands.— Called at Mr: King’s. He is not returned.

13. We dined at Mr: S. Vaughan’s at Hackney.— His son William Mr: Belsham a clergyman and his brother and Sister, Miss Hallowell, and Mr: W. N. Boylston were of the Company. Mr: Vaughan shewed us some interesting original portraits—of Erasmus by Holbein—of Hobbes.—of Locke— Of Pope by Jarvis &c.— Mr: Boylston came home partly with us.— News this day received of an Action between the English & Dutch fleets in the North Sea, off the Coast of Holland. Illuminations.

14. Mr: King called to see me. Returned from his tour last Evening. Conversation with him.— Dined with Mr: Murdoch.— Mrs: A. with Mrs: Court.— A number of Gentlemen, at Mr: Murdoch’s. Home early. Illuminations in the Evening, again.

15. Late this morning. From an inevitable cause.— Went to the foundling Church. Heard Dr: Gaskin an indifferent, and singular preacher.— Mrs: A. unwell.— Called at Mr: Pinckney’s. They were not to be seen.— found him at Mr: King’s; and a Mr: Elmsly who comes to be Mr: Kings Secretary. As I was coming home, met Hall and Jeffrey. Evening at home looking over reviews.

16. Busy in preparing for departure which is yet postponed from day to day.— Town resounding with the particulars of the late naval action.— Excused from dining with Mr: King.— Evening at Mrs: Court’s. Heard Mr: Eyre sing, and was much pleased with her.— General Illuminations, the third Evening.— In this land of freedom and regular Government, mobs are going about every evening of illumination, compelling people to light, and breaking the windows of all who decline compliance. They were this Night very troublesome; and noisy till after 2 in the morning. We returned late from Mrs: Court’s.

17. Employed in the forenoon getting ready to go. The ship at length sailed. We are to join her at Gravesend; and intend going to-morrow morning. Dined at Mr: King’s.— They are much pleased with their late tour into Wales, and told us many particulars of their Journey. Home early— Under great anxiety on account of the voyage and journey we have to go through. Mr: Pinckney & Mr: Hall called to see me.

18. Busied in the morning about town with the last preparations for departure. Sent Whitcomb to the Duke of Portland’s Office, with my Passport from Mr: King, to procure an order permitting me to embark. a Clerk took the Passport, and required my personal attendance at the Office, before he could expedite the Passport Order. I went accordingly. The clerk who had my Passport was gone out. The doorkeeper said he
would perhaps return between 2 & 3 o’clock, and evaded my repeated enquiries what was his name. I asked him his own name. He said his name was Mr: Thru—a German name.— Finding myself thus deprived of my Passport, I left Whitcomb to wait for the return of the Clerk, and immediately went home and wrote to Mr: King, stating the circumstances and requesting another Passport; being under the greatest apprehension of losing my passage in consequence of this detention.— Hall told me I could get such an order as I wanted, at the magistrate’s Office in Bow-Street— Went with him there; but no order could be had till seven in the Evening, for which I could not stay.— At about 1/2 past 3. my brother returned from Mr: King’s with the second Passport, and about the same time Whitcomb came from the Duke’s Office with the other, but without the order. I wrote again to Mr: King desiring if possible that the order might be sent down after me to Gravesend to-night; and just before 4. we stepped into the Post-Chaise. Between 7 and 8 we arrived there. The ship had been gone down about 2 hours before. She was however to anchor for the night at the Hope, about 10 miles below. I was reduced to the alternative of losing my passage, or of going down to the ship in an open rowing boat.— Upon application to Mr: Mazzinghi, he without hesitation gave me the permission to embark, though I had not the order, which in the case of neutral Countries, he told me was expedited not at the Duke of Portland’s Office, but by a magistrate.— We went into the Boat just at 8. The evening was remarkably fine, and at about 10, we reached the ship.— Mrs: Adams was sick immediately upon our getting on board the vessel.

19. We sailed from the Hope, at about 5 this morning. The day was very beautiful, and the water perfectly smooth; but with so little wind that in the course of the day we only got down the river and anchored at night somewhat below Sheerness. The ship is a good one, but the want of cleanliness on board is great, and very disgusting.— We have besides ourselves four passengers.— Two of them Jews.

20. A Rainy and very uncomfortable day. The wind was not favourable during the former part of it, and between 3 and 4. P.M. the Captain stood in to the land, intending to anchor off Harwich, this night. But the wind soon after came round, and we struck off to Sea. Blew a fresh gale all night.

21. Violent gale of wind through the whole day. Ship rolled a great deal, though Dutch built and a very strong tight vessel. Almost sick myself. Most of the other passengers entirely so. Fortunately the wind is fair and carries us rapidly to the place of our destination— Late in the Evening the storm abated and the weather became fine.

22. Weather bad. Rainy great part of the day; but the wind was not high, and the sea was much smoother than yesterday. At about 9 this Evening the light upon Helegoland was discovered. Mrs: A. has been very sick, but all things considered has borne the voyage remarkably well.

23. This morning upon rising I found we had a pilot on board, and were in sight of land: it was the island of Neuwerk, at the mouth of the river Elbe. The day was fine, but the wind adverse. We passed Cuxhaven at about noon, and anchored at about six leagues above it, opposite Brunsbuttel, a little before six in the Evening.— Night very fair. The banks of the Elbe are not unpleasant, but exhibit neither the cultivation, the taste nor the elegance of the Thames or of some french rivers; or even of the Rhine— Read this Evening some pages of Count Fathom, the most indifferent of Smollett’s novels. It happens to be almost the only book I have at hand.

24. The wind blew fresh down the river the whole of this day; so that we could only take advantage of one tide from noon to sunset to beat up about 5 leagues as high as Glückstadt. The banks of the river have still nothing remarkable. The land is low. The right banks are the Hanoverian, and the left, the Danish dominions.— Read part of Falconer’s Shipwreck; a poem of considerable merit.

25. The wind continues directly a head, and blew quite a gale all the former part of the day. With the change of tide, between two and three however we got under weight, and ascended the river four or five leagues further. Anchored again not far above Stade.— Read the remainder of Falconer’s Shipwreck; Collins’s oriental eclogues, and some of his Odes.— To avoid a custom house entrance and inspection at Hamburg, our baggage was declared at Stade.

26. At nine this morning we anchored in the Port of Hamburg. Left Whitcomb on board to land our baggage and came on shore with a boat belonging to the place; an Officer from a guard house on our passage took our names &c and enquired whether we were emigrants.— From the landing place we came to the King of England Hotel.— Got the baggage in the course of the day.— Called in the afternoon upon Mr: Williams the American Consul, and an old acquaintance of mine.— My brother found Messrs: Ross and Calhoun, both here.

27. Went this morning to visit, Mr: Peyron the Swedish Minister, Mr: Parish, & Mr: Voght with all of whom I have formerly been acquainted. Found none of them. Mr: Williams called upon us. Messrs: Ross and Calhoun at tea, and pass’d part of the evening with us.— Getting the carriage on shore and making enquiries to prepare for our Journey.— Mr: Parish called to see me, and invited us to dine with him in the Country on Sunday. Took a ride with Mrs: A to Altena.

28. At the Bookseller Fauche’s and purchased a book of German roads. Visit from my old friend Mr: Peyron— He says the king of Prussia can live but a few days longer if he be not already dead. Called to see Mr: Cadignan, who is here and confined to his bed with a rhumatism in his head. We dined with Mr: Williams, where we met several American Gentlemen. Among the rest Mr: Coolidge of Boston, whom I saw about three months ago in London.— Evening at home.

29. Wrote a little in the morning. Between 12 and 1. rode out to Mr: Parish’s in the Country on the banks of the Elbe about 5 miles distant from the town. Dined there. Mr: Parish shewed me his correspondence with the imperial Minister and the Baron de Thugut relative to the liberation of the Prisoners at Olmütz. They are now gone into Holstein.— My brother and Mr: Ross stay the night to attend a Ball in the neighbourhood. We were obliged to come away just after 4, as at sunset the gates of the City are shut for the night, a practice founded upon the vicinity of Altena, and the other jurisdictions which surround Hamburg. It is said to have also a fiscal view, as the principal revenues of the place are from an excise.— Evening at home reading Miss Wollstonecraft’s letters from Sweden and Norway. There is some imagination & some reflection: but a canting whining sickly style of complaint, and almost as many errors as ideas.

30. Several visitors, and invitations this forenoon. From Mr: Peyron, and Mr: Voght which we declined as we are decided to set out on Wednesday morning. Mr: Baurmeister the partner of Mr: Voght called upon us and made us many civil apologies in behalf of Mr: Voght who is not in town.— Went to two Booksellers. purchased an English & German Dictionary and a French and German Grammar. Mr: Williams called upon us before dinner.— We went in the Evening to the French play. Mr: Parish furnished us with tickets for his box. L’optimiste of Collin d’Harleville; and Le secret—an opera comique. The performers pretty good.— Singing tolerable. The boxes are held by subscription for the Season.

31. Mr: Ross and Mr Frank Williams the Consul’s brother, have determined to bear us company to Berlin. We had fixed upon to-morrow for our departure. But have not been able to get entirely ready, and therefore postpone it until the next day. I endeavoured this morning to find Mr: Williams’s House, but was disappointed.— Mr: Ross dined with us.
Day. Travelling, by Sea and Land, it has of course been irregular. I hope for some sort of settled life, at a future day; but for the present must submit to my destiny.
